hu.trigary.iodine.api

Class IodineApi

  • java.lang.Object
    • hu.trigary.iodine.api.IodineApi

  • public abstract class IodineApi
extends java.lang.Object
    The API plugins should use to have access to Iodine's features. An instance of this class can be obtained through the get() getter.

    When the Iodine plugin gets disabled all IodineGui instances are closed without calling the IodineGui.onClosed(IodineGui.ClosedAction) callback. For this reason some plugins might have to listen to the plugin disable event and gracefully close the GUIs there.

    It is worth noting that generally speaking values which are representable on 15 bits are supported, or 14 bits in case negative values are also valid. While the API works with 32 bit integers, the implementation prefers 16 bit shorts and variable-length encoding to reduce payload size.

      • addListener

        public abstract <T extends IodineEvent> void addListener(@NotNull
                                                         @NotNull java.lang.Class<T> event,
                                                         @NotNull
                                                         @NotNull java.lang.String plugin,
                                                         @NotNull
                                                         @NotNull java.util.function.Consumer<T> handler)
        Registers an event listener. Handler instances can be unregistered using the removeListener(Class, Consumer) method. The listener is automatically unregistered when the specified plugin gets disabled.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the event
        Parameters:
        event - the event to listen for
        plugin - the exact name of the plugin that is registering the listener
        handler - the handler of the event

      • removeListener

        public abstract <T extends IodineEvent> boolean removeListener(@NotNull
                                                               @NotNull java.lang.Class<T> event,
                                                               @NotNull
                                                               @NotNull java.util.function.Consumer<T> handler)
        Unregisters an event listener. Keep in mind that the handler instance must be the exact same one passed to the addListener(Class, String, Consumer) method. Considering using assertions on the return value to detect such bugs.
        Type Parameters:
        T - the type of the event
        Parameters:
        event - the event to listen for
        handler - the handler of the event
        Returns:
        true if the handler was actually removed, false if it wasn't registered
